top_categories.workout_context: At mile 60 of 124, glycogen is gone. This workout teaches your body to produce watts on fumes.
The Rift's Black volcanic sand, sharp lava rock forces constant power changes. Surge over the rough stuff, settle on the smooth, repeat for 124 miles.
Race-pace efforts that mimic The Rift's demands. Pacing, fueling, and tactical decisions under fatigue. Practice the race before July.
52ft/mi means long efforts at or near FTP on every climb. If your threshold cracks at minute 15, you'll walk the rest.
Every hard session works better with a bigger aerobic base. At 124 miles, base fitness is the difference between racing and surviving.
At The Rift, surges push you above threshold and you have to recover while still riding. Over-unders train exactly that.
How long can you hold 105% FTP before you blow? At The Rift, that number decides whether you bridge or get dropped.
88–92% FTP is where you'll spend the hardest sustained miles of The Rift. Train it until it feels boring.
6,400ft of climbing means repeated surges above threshold. VO2max work is how you survive the fifth climb, not just the first.
124 miles rewards fat oxidation. This volume work shifts your fuel mix so you're still burning fat at hour 5, not bonking at hour 3.
Short, max efforts are unavoidable. Punchy climbs, gap closures, attacks on black volcanic sand and sharp lava rock. If you haven't trained them, you'll crack.
Endurance with intensity spikes baked in. Exactly what 6,400ft of climbing on black volcanic sand and sharp lava rock does to your power file on race day.

race_overlay.heat: July in Hvolsvöllur, Southern Iceland — 10-15°C (50-59°F) with extreme variability. Cold + wet + wind. Hypothermia risk is real. Begin heat acclimatization 10–14 days before The Rift — 20–30min sauna sessions or midday rides in full kit. Pre-load sodium 48 hours out. Target 500–750ml/hr with electrolytes on race day.
race_overlay.nutrition: Target 60–80g carbs/hour for The Rift’s 124 miles. Start fueling within the first 30 minutes — early fueling prevents late-race collapse. Bonking at mile 60 is a nutrition failure, not a fitness failure.
race_overlay.terrain: Highly technical terrain at The Rift demands practice on similar surfaces. Ride black volcanic sand and sharp lava rock at race-day cadence weekly. Expect: black volcanic sand, sharp lava rock, loose highland roads. Practice cornering, descending, and power delivery on unstable surfaces. Dial in tire pressure before race week — 5 PSI wrong costs you 15+ minutes over 124 miles.

pack_summary: This 10-workout pack focuses on Durability, Gravel Specific, and Race Simulation to prepare you for 124 miles of black volcanic sand and sharp lava rock in Hvolsvöllur, Southern Iceland.
